div.head: COUCHED IN FRIENDLY TONE
div.p: Paris, June 27 Prince Radohm presented Germany's reply to the French note of the 22nd inst. It is understood that it insists upon the necessity a Congress and considers a previous discus sion as to its scope unnecessary, but the gene ral tenour is so amicable that it appears to facilitate the granting of the purely formal consessions to which Germany appears attach value. It makes it difficult for France to refuse a Conference, especially as her excep- tional position on the Moroccan frontier is fully acknowledged. The prohibition of tho importation of muni- tions, which has already placed the Sultans force at Ujida in a most critical position, has been withdrawn. (Reuter.)

Paws, June i M. Rouvier has received Germany’s reply which persists in demanding a conference with- out any previous understanding. The reply is couched in a friendly spirit, which will facilitate the granting by France of purely formal con- cessions. (Havas.)
The Brindisi Mail will be distributed at the G.P.O., Alexandria, at 9.30 p.m. to-day. !
The Moilki Saidna Hussein was celebrat ed last night in the quarter of Cairo that bears the name of the nephew of the Prophet
Prize Distribution —M. Buusquol, French Consul at Cairo, will prosido over the dis tribution of prizes to the pupils of the Ecole Jeanne d’Arc Fagalla at 5pm this (Wednesday) afternoon.
Warsaw, June 27. The soldiers have stormed and destroyed six barricades. There are 10 wounded in other conflicts with Cossack patrols. (Reuter.)
Lodz, June 27. The repetition of the massacre has been pievented by an overwhelming military force and heavy rain 20000 Jews have quitted the town (R.)

St. Petersburg, June 27. A Ukase invests tho Governor General of Warsaw with supremo military powers, which General Trepoff is proceeding to Warsaw to exercise on his behalf. There have been 672 arrests, mostly Jews, and the prisons are full. (Reuter.)

div.head: FRENCH AMNESTY
div.p: Paris, June 27. The French Government has introduced a bill granting amnesty to M Deruulede and his . exiles, and also covering offences relating to strikes. the press, and the informing scandals (Reuter.)

div.head: OFFICIAL REPORT ON FIGHTING
div.p: Berlin, June 27. The German official despatches show that desperate fighting lasted 14 hours, but that finally Marengo s position was captured They deny the capture of Warmbad ( Neuter.)
Stray and Ownerless Dogs found between the Pont des Anglais and the Ghizeh Mou- dirieh during the nights of Thursday and Friday and at dawn on Friday and Saturday, will be poisoned by the police.

Zeitoun.— We hear that the Ministry of Public Works proposes to undertake the con- struction of metalled roads at Zeitoun in the autumn. The construction of a new railway station will also be commenced.

A Jailbird.— Shamroukh Meloka, brother of tho notorious Androus, has just been released from prison, where he has passed 6 years. He has been sent to the El Dorr Markas, where he will remain under observation by the police.

div.head: DISTRIBUTION OF PRIZES.
div.p: The prize distribution to the cadets of the Military School, Cairo, took place at 8 o'olock this in morning before a large gathering of officers. Amongst those present we noticed Kaimakam Herbert Bey, A.A.G., Kaimakam Anderson Bey, Director of Stores, Bimbashi Carey, officer commanding 16th Battalion, Miralai Zaky Bey, A.A.G., Miralai Tewfik Bey, Kaimakam Sabri Bey. D.A.A.G., the whole staff of the school, , and a large number of junior officers. Mr. Biyau, senior master, read his report on the indoor work of the school, with the results of the recent examinations, and this was follow- ed by Mr. Plunkett's report on the outdoor work, football, athletic sports, etc., after which Miralai Matchett Bey distributed the prizes. In making his address to the cadets Matchett Beyy expressed his great regret that neither the Minister of War nor H.B. the Sirdar were able to attend, but this was made impossible by the time of the year at which the distribu- tion was held. I The proceedings were then brought to a con- clusion by tho cadets giving three times the "Eftendimez Chok Yasha." A fuller account of the ceremony, with a list of the prizes and commissions, will be publish- ed i. o n issue of tomorrow.

div.head: LEGISLATIVE COUNCIL
div.p: Tho Legislative Council will meet to-morrow. The Prosident will present Ibrahim Effendi Abd-el-AL the new delegate of the Fayoum province, to the members of the Council. The Council will examine the question of forming the Armenian Catholics of Egypt into a 'Community "

Victoria House and Nurses Home.- Miss Waeber, the matron, has gone to Europe on three months' furlough, and her place will be taken by Miss Harbord. The registry office will be closed during Miss Waebers absence and will be opened again on 1st October.

Suez Canal.— 19 vessels passed through the Canal on the 24th and 25th inst, of which 10 were British, 5 German, 1 American, 1 Turkish, 1 Italian, 1 French. The receipts for the two days were frs. 526,503, making the total from the 1st inst. frs. 6.962,326.62.

Um Rush. The Committee of the London Stock Exchange have fixed Wednesday, July 19, as a special settling day in Um Rus Gold Mines of Egypt, Limited - Further issue of 30,000 shares of 1 each, 10s paid (Nos. 150,001 to 180,000)

div.head: NAVAL AND MILITARY MEASURES
div.p: Christiania. June 27. Sweden is adopting certain naval and military measures which are creating a dis agreeable impression here, although it is ex- plained that they are purely precautional. It is generally believed that notwithstanding the aggressive language of the Swedish Conserva tives, the disunion will be peacefully arranged. (Reuter.)

"Avon" Stabbing Cadr —The trial of John Raghy, cook of the S.S. "Avon," on the charge of stabbing the steward of the ship, J. E. Garnham, under circumstances already related in our columns, will take place at H.B.M. s Consular Court, Alexandria, on Saturday.

The Plague. — Yesterday’ss bulletin records a fatal case at Alexandria, the victim being a native who worked in a cafe near Mohamed Aly square, and who was found dead at his house. Three new cases and two deaths are reported trom Damanbour, and one case from Toukh district.

The Pigmies seem to be in rather an awk ward position. They have beheld many won ders and miracles, says the "Express," but of these they must remain silent when they return home, or they will certainly be burned to death as being possessed of devils. This will be a blow to publishers in the Ituri Forest

div.head: HOME CRICKET
div.p: London, June 27. Worcestershire beat Leicestershire by an innings and 207 runs. M.C.C. beat Cambridge University by 4 wickets. (Reuter.)

The Cotton Worm.— The School of Agri culture has placed the services of two of their instructors, Mr. W. Cartwright and Mr. G Bonaparte, at the disposal of the Ministry of the Interior for cotton-worm duty, and these two gentleman hare accordingly been posted to the Mudiriehs of Ghizeh and Behera, res pectively
AFal-kAlarm — Androns Meloka's exploits appear to hav^. had their effect in putting travellers by train very much on the ywi rive.

div.head: CONCESSION BY THE PORTE.
div.p: We learn from Constantinople that after two years' efforts on the part of the British Embassy, the Porte has finally agreed to grant the same privilege — namely, exemption of Customs duty on coal—to the ships of the Khedivial Mail Company as that enjoyed by the other foreign mail steamers. The Porte's objection as regards the Khedivial Mail Com pany has been that their vessels ply between Ottoman ports, and, therefore, do not come under the same category as the other foreign companies, whose ports of origin are in foreign countries As a matter of fact, however, tho Turkish Government has never been able to forgive the Khedivial Company for transferring its ships to the British flag, hence all the trouble over this and other facilities.

div.head: DREDGERS PROPOSED FOR WHITE NILE.
div.p: The Council of Ministers has approved the proportion of the Ministry of Public Works that Mr. Dapuis, Inspector General of Irriga tion in the Sudan, should be sent on a mission to the United States and Canada and, if pos sible, should also visit Holland and Germany, in order to examine on the spot the different types of dredgers which are in use in those countries, and which are of the most advanced form and of great working capacity. Mr. Dupuis will spend some two months in examining this question, and will present his report on the results of his inspection immediately after his return to this country. It is considered that these dredgers are necessary tor ameliorating the condition of the White Nile for the purpose of increasing the supply of water in Egypt

div.head: PRICE OF LAND AT GHEZIREH
div.p: In reference to the great rise within the past year or so in the price of land for building purposes near Cairo, in localities that have of late greatly appreciated in public estimation, we may instance that in the neighbourhood of Ghezireh Palace Hotel. No plots heeo can now be had under P.T 3on per square metre. The sites belonging to the Ghezireh Land Company, which purchased three years ago some 81 feddaus in this locality, are selling at from P.T. 62 to P.T. 156 per square metre, the latter price being asked for the more attractive lots bordering on the Nile. The land was divid- ed into 133 lots, of which 65 have already been disposed of. To the south of the above property the War Office owns a small one, whilst between the latter property and the public gardens, in which is situated the grotto, the lands belong to the Government, one side of these lace the road running parallel with the Nile branch or canal, and the other the Ghezireh Palace property, which is also being rapidly built over.

div.head: THE YEMEN CAMPAIGN.
div.p: Renter's Agency states that the reinforce- ments for the Yemen have also arrived at Hodeida with the exception of the Malaria Red if (Reserve) Brigade and will, according to the latest advices,ad vance on SanAt by Menakha, while the other will move by Tais. The Otto man authorities wish to recapture Sanaa, lbb,- and the other towns in the possession of the Imam’s forces before treating with the rebels. It may be presumed that their real aim is the complete destruction of the insurgent forces, after which pourparlers will be greatly simplified. Another telegram states that the insurgents are on the march to Mecca and that Faizi Pasha, who has arrived at Hodeida, declares that it is absolutely impossible to stop their advance. It this statement is reliable it point# to an extension of the revolt from the Yemen province to the Azir district, which is inhabit ed by the Beni Kahtan, Beni Thakif, and Beni Otaiba Bedouins. Tais, from which one of the Turkish co- lumns is to start, is close to the frontier of the Aden protectorate and about 70 miles from the coast Menakha, which it about the same distance from Hodeida, is only 40 miles from Sanaa, but an army advancing to the recapture of the headquarters of the Vllth Army Corps will be obliged to fight its way across a formidable mountain range whose highest peaks are over 7,000 feet above sea level.

div.head: 1SMAILIA.
div.p: Last year, with the view of encouraging owners of vessels, after discharging coal at Port Raid, to load at Ismailia, and to prevent, if possible, the complete decadence of the latter town, which is practically owned by the Baez Canal Company, the latter adopted a very wise measure to try and counteract the injury to the place brought about by the opening of the new through line from Cairo to Port Baud The measure was that such vessels should pay only the very reduced tax of 2 frs. 60 c. per registered ton for the double journey from Port Said to Ismailia and back, instead of the usual rate of 4 francs each way, the through rate from end to end, i.e., From Port Said to Suez, or vice versa, being now 2 Ir 5o c. per ton. The advantage to exporters from the districts near, like Zagazig, Tantah, and even Benha, was great, since ship- pers from Ismalia economise the heavy railway freigbt from the latter station to Port Said, which is more than the very moderate charge ot 2 fr. 60c. fixed by the Canal Company. The company furthermore proposed,should the experiment prove remunerative, to construct moles and jetties for the accommodation of vessels, and do all it could to facilitate loading operations. From what we hear, it does not seem that the result so far has come up to expectations, and the town appears to be languishing for want of some enterprise that will stimulate its gradually dying trade, which was however never of much account The decision taken two years back by the P. and O. and other large com panies to embark and disembark their local passengers at Port Said instead of Ismailia, as formerly, was another nail in the latter's coffin, for we hear that tho management of Shepheard's Hotel, who rented formerly the Hotel Victoria at Ismailia from Mr. Marini, the proprietor, has decided not to renew the lease of ten years which has just expired.

It now appears that Mohamed el Maghazi, who boarded a first class carriage near Maghagba aud was seized by tbs occupant*, was after 1 all an employe of the 8urvsy Department who 1 jumped on to a moving train without a ticket, 1 and climbed into the first carriage that pro- ' seated itself.

div.head: COLONEL MARCHAND
div.p: Colonel Marc recently contributed to the "Matin" an important and most interesting account of the origin of the Fashoda expedi- tion. It was on Nov. 16, 1895, that M. Ber- thelot, Minister of Foreign Affairs, signed and approved of his plan for French intervention in the Bahr el-Ghazal and on the Nila The scheme, however, lay dormant until the follow- ing spring, when the Sudan expedition was announced by England. The attitude of the French Government changed immediately. M. Guioysso, the Minister of tho Colonies, im- plored the writer to start as soon as possible, and if he had obeyed he would have left within forty eight hours, vompletely unpre- pared for a journey over 10,000 kilometres of country. M. Barthelot, who bad so for- gotton himself as to) tell Lord Salisbury that he declined all responsibility for the consequences to which the Sudan expedi- tion might lead, quitted the Quai d'Orsay a few days after he had used such peculiar language, and as M. Leon Bourgeois, the Pre- sident of the Council, could not find anyone to succeed him he took his place. About the first thing that M. Bourgeois did was to send for Colonel Marchand, preparations for whose journey were then hurried on. This was in March, 1896, and a few weeks later the Bourgeois Ministry fell, and was replaced by the Meline Cabinet, with M. Hanotaux at the Ministry of Foreign A Hairs. M. Andrfi Lebon, the new Minister of the Colonic-, was not so generous in the matter of resources as M. Bourgeois would have been, but the writer was again enjoined to start as soon as he could. The first convoy sailed from Bordeaux on April 25, the others being transported in the steamers that followed. Colonel Marchand himself left Marseilles on June 25, 1896, at which date the troops which were to accom- pany him across Africa for the occupation of Fashoda, if they arrived there before the British army, were completing their movement from Timbuctoo on Dakar and on Libreville, in the French Congo. The writer says that his officers and his own companions in the expedi- tion were not aware of its destination until eighteen months afterwards, when they were in the very heart of Central Africa. It has often been affirmed that M. Delcasse had something to do with the organisation of the Fashoda expedition. Colonel Marchand, how- ever, terminates his instructive explanation with the following emphatic words which close "M. Deloasec, whom I hardly knew, and who from February, 1895, to July, 1898, had no share in the Government-the very reverse, indeed, was the case—had nothing, absolutely nothing, to do with the consideration, the pre paration, and the execution of an expedition of which he only became informed to pot an end to it in October, 1898. All that has been said contrary to this affirmation, which 1 make on my honor, and which is based on history itself, which can easily be examined, is only e tale, which 1 wish now to demolish with one blow, as 1 think that the time has come for me to do so." Thus does Colonel Marchand dispose of one of the charges brought against the late Minister of Foreign Affairs, which was to the effect that, although be had been an active promoter of the Fashoda expedition, he deserted Colonel Marchand when England adopted a resolute attitude. Colonel Marchand's explanation has created quite a sensation in political circles.

div.head: THEATRE.
div.p: During a performance at Minieh of an Arabic drama bearing the thrilling title of Love and Revenge, by Sheikh Salema Hegazi and his company, a dentist suddenly rose from bis seat and rushed upon one of the occupants of a box with drawn dagger. The victim of the dentist's onslaught shouted for help, and the police, aided by the cooler-headed spectators, disarmed and arrested his assailant. An Arabic contemporary states that the dentist, whom we will call Mr. X, had been very intimate with Y, the individual whom be attempted to stab. The two lived in the same house, and X eventually was trustful enough to leave his wife in Y’s charge while paying a visit to his old borne in Syria. The dentist returned in due course and found neither his wife nor the furniture. The ingenious Y had informed X's father and mother in- law that he had fled the country owing to debts caused by the extravagance of his wife. They promptly sold the furniture and took B their daughter away with them. Y then brought in other lodgers, whom he considered more profitable acquaintances than the luckless X. whose resentment at the brutal practical joke played upon him was, no doubt, too violently expressed, but can easily be unders- tood.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Lord Edward Cecil Pasha, D.8.O., is expect ed to arrive et Cairo next Wednesday on the completion of his leave.
Mr. H. Boyle will leave for England early in July
Capt. McMurdo, head of the Slave Trade Department, is expected to arrive in Cairo from his inspecting tour up the White Nile on friday next.
The death is announced of Doctor Roger, former medical surgeon attached to the French Ethiopian Railways, and chief medical officer who accompanied the Rothschild Mission across Abyssinia and Uganda.
Major R N. Gamble, D.S.O., 2nd Battalion R. Berkshire Regiment, has been granted leave of absence for three months.
Mr. C. Aquilina, proprietor of the Carlton Hotel, Bulkeley, has returned to Alexandria from Malta.

Among the latest arrivals at the Savoy Hotel, Port Said, we notice Pastor Kahle, Dr. end Mme. Wild. Mr. Saint Port Mortier, Mr. Cameo. Mr. Vincent, M and Mme. Doom moot, Mahmoud Bey Saddik, Mr. A. Kings Brothers. Mr. T. A. Sean, Major Persse Bey, Major Matthews, Capt. Rome, Capt C. Ehyall, Orphi Bey, Gibson Pasha, Capt Adams, Mr. and Mr*. 8. Heath, Mr. and A Sou, Mr. T. A. W. div.head: SUMMER SEASON COMMENCES.
div.p: (From our Correspondent). Nicosia, June 22. Several storm* have been reported daring the last few day* as having occnrred in various parts of the Island. Yesterday it was learnt that a portion of the road leading to Mt Troo- dos had been rendered impassable to traffic owing to debris that had been washed down by heavy rains. Unfortunately this road will have to be much used this week, in consequence of the departure today of his Excellency and the Secretariat for the summer quartan on Troodos. The summer season may now be said to bare commenced, and will probably continue, as usual until about the second week ot October, when, as a rule, the Government returns to Nicosia. The heat in the plains has. been so far much lass severe than usual -. nevertheless most officials will welcome the change to higher altitudes, lie battalion of the King’s Royal Rifles has already arrived at Troodos from Polemedia Camp.

div.head: GREEK SCHOOL COMMITTEE.
div.p: This week was held the first election, under the new Education Law, of the Creak School Committee for Nicosia. As a good deal of party feeling exists in the Island owing to the divisions censed by the vexed Archiepiscopel question, which still remains open, this new opportunity for a party display caused con- siderable excitement, and it is not yet general- ly known which party was successful at the

div.head: A MOSLEM CEREMONY.
div.p: The ceremony of inaugurating the newly- built minaret of the Eomerie Mosque in Nico- sia took place yesterday in the presence of his Excellency and Indy King Ham an and several officials. The function was largely attended by the Moslem community.

div.head: BNCOURAGING PLORICULTURK
div.p: A public garden has been laid out at Limas sol this winter. This was a pet scheme of the late High Commissioner, Sir William p. Haynes-Smith, and is likely to add largely to the attraction* of that town. . It it gradually getting planted, and in course of time should provide a pleasant lounge for the residents. The Government Nursery Garden adjoins it, where a number of plants are raised and can easily be transplanted. There is also a Govern- ment Nursery Garden at Larnaca, and both a nursery end an experimental garden at Nico- sia. Forest end trait trees in large nursery are raised in these gardens, as well u many flowering plants and shrub*, palms, etc., in pots, which are sold to the public at very low cost. Grafts and buds are also obtain- able, and it is the object of the Govern- ment by this means to encourage tree planting and the cultivation of good kinds of fruit Similar gardens are doing useful work in other part* of the Island, bat there is room for an extension in this direction. It is hoped that before long they will be used for the practical purpose of demonstrating various methods of cultivation.

div.head: TH* WmUJ OlMWl; WEDICESBAT, JBNB 23,. 1*06.
div.p: O.N’-THB IIKDJAZ R VILWAY. South of Denia, the cultivation rapidly ceased, and for two or three hours wo ra-> through oountry that bore the greatest like nos to the Marioat steppe at the end o' April. There was the same burnt grass and grey boulders, but if the ground was les stony on the data it was far more rocky o the slopes of the low hills which we passed from time to time. On the west the hill cou:: try of Edom was marked by low rounded summits. Eastward stretched immonso open plains that gavo the same impression of spa ciousness as the Arabian desert soon from the Canal near el Kantara or from tho railway at Zeitoun. The foreground was yellow brown, relieved by t>c visional grey patches anj dotted with the dark green desert scrub, tho background was an almost uniform fawa co- lour which deepened to a dull red wheu the sun began to set. As far as natural feature*, inhabitants, or cultivation went this section of tho lino was a ‘perfect and absolute blank.' There were hills, it is true, but their Ion» glacis and rounded summits doprived them of any pfeturesqueoess.

There wore no Bedouins, goats or camels to bo scon and the only men we passed were the littlo groups ot soldier railwayman at two or three stations where the eugino nn 1 the passengers took in water for a few m: notes. On this sefition, too, tho rails were worn and the train left each of these stations with a horrid jerk. Some of the passengers were always on their feet whenever this oc curred and were always thing violently into tho laps of their vis-kvis by tho sudl>n shock, to the groat contentment of all llioir fellows.

At night fell wo began to enter close, brokon oountry, full of low stoay hills covered with boulders and withered grass, and aoimod by dry wadis near which tho vegetation was still fairly fresh. The comments of a London daily on the good that the Hodja* line will do by "opening np ths country to trade" recurred to me just then and I felt that the writer of the article I had >n mind oonld nover have seen this part of the world, which looked incapable of supporting any indnstry but the raising of an inferior breed of goats. There were pockets among these low hills where I expected to see signs of a rain crop, but either the soil was bad or the Bedouins did not tronblo to sow barley a* thoir cousins do in the Marioat district. At about 7 p.m. 1 opened a tin of meat, which, by the way, disagreed with me mightily, and was rather annoyed at the in- tense cariosity shown by the occupants of the carriage, who believed—so 1 afterwards learnt from the guard,—that 1 was eating pork. After all I bad no reason for my annoyance. Do not snme Englishmen wbo have, not left their island still hold that the Frenchman subsists on salads, frogs, and snails, and does not the nntravelled Haul ascribe an unchanging diet of "pellel" and "biftock" to the carnivorous Saxon ? Still 1 felt inclined to make a diversion and having a big of lemons and some soda water 1 stood lemon squash to the occupants of my end of the carriage, who seemed highly satisfied therewith and always thanked me most po'itely. After my meal I tried to sleep ou my boards and a conch made of a greatcoat and a rug but the carriage required a thorough disiDfeotion and insect powders were poworlres, all the wingless and irritant species being well ropre anted. Near 'Arnnjn 1 fell off the board and rema'ued awake and angry till we ran into the station.

AmmAn (Rabb.ath Ammon) is a garrison to sin. Turkish soldiers and Circassian colonists are posted there, and there is a small popula- tion of fellaheen and settled Be lonins with a few Italian workmen and a handful o' Syrians. The great R imsn cistern is the fe stare of the place—I mcstreto theourious to Biedeker for its measurements and history—the town itkplf be:hg simply a colleitioa of tents and dirty hovels. Prom a military pnint of view the town is of some importance. Corn is grown on the mountains bard by ; there is pemanent Water in the heads of the Zirka which rise iu the 'AmmAn hills, and the garrison both 1 defends that section of the line where damage 1 Would bo hardest to repair and watches the 1 Bedouins who roam about the edge of the 1 desert and who, till lately, blackmailed the 1 fellaheen, killed stray Turks, and arranged 1 attacks ou terrific 1 tourists with the aid of 1 the venal dragoman. The arrival of the Circas- 1 sians has changed all this, though I gather 1 that the Tcherkeia can be a more expert and 1 redoubtable highwayman than the most piotu- 1 the air by way of impressing him with his ] prowess before asking him to stand and dolivet. I 1 walked about ths Amman station and the | steep bill above it for some time, bat the grouud was full of holes, and the attentions 1 received from the dogs of the placo were so I persistent that I returned to tho oarriage and 1 triod to sloop. After various misadventures ,1 suoceoied, only to be awakonod by tho terrific shock with which wo started, and the lamenta- tions of a soldier who had broken a window in trying to shut it and was being reviled by tho guard. Wo were far less crowded on this part of the journey—Hamdulillah I —so that, the atmosphere produced by the closing of all the unbroken windows and tho nse of quantities of tobacco was jost boarablo. 1 awoke ot about 3 am. feeling very aoro and unhappy and found the train running tbrongh a steppe which was a littlo yellowor bat otherwise an exact replica of the oountry whioh wo had paasod between Dents and Amman. At about 6 a.m. we passed a caravan (lying two Osmanli flags marching along a sort of cart-track to Katraneh. A few tatterdemalion.! with rifles redo ahead on mules, then came in single file 8 camels carrying women and bales, a cart carry- ing packed tents and projecting tent polos, some women and children and a soldier riding slowly on a bay Arab. From the camels to the children ovary member of the caravan seemed to be walking in his sleep. Tho soldier and the nondescripts on males waved to ns,and thou relapsed into an apathetic progress, and it was only when I got out on the tail board of tho Cirri age and felt the wind and saw how tho women were huddling their clothes round their bodios, that 1 realise! that they wore all numb- ed with the oold of the desort morniug. (To be continued).

SCI)AN CAMPAIGNING. BENNETT BURLEIGH REMINISCENT. The veteran War Correspondent Mr. Ben- nett Burleigh writes to the "Daily Telegraph" on the subject of rifle shooting "I have seen most of the fighting in Egypt and tho Sudan between the years 1882 and 1898. Indifferent as was the shooting of onr soldiers in those days, it was their great supe- riority in marksmanship overtbatof the enemy that won ns so many victories withbutahandful of troops. We ought to have been eaten np or drivon into the sea more than onoe, say as at El Magfar, Hassassip, and Tamai. The Marine*, by their steady fire discipline, had much to do with saving the situation at all three of these actions ; and at the surprise at Hassassin lock, the 60th Rifles, who deployed to the front at the ‘ double’’ out ol camp, instantly checked the further advance of Arabi Pasha’s horse and foot. They were pounded with Krupp cannon- shells, but the riflemen never budged, except to creep nearer to the foe. Wheu the machine- guns were temporarily lost at Tamai, Genera' Sir Gerald Graham ro formed Davis's broken brigade, uot in square but in line, and order- ed them forward to recover the groond and the battery. That day, at Colonel Tuson’s (of the Marines,! request, 1 acted for the nonoe as gal- loper. Firing steadily as they advanced, stage by stage, the Dervish Fcny-Wuizy, who is the finest fighting-man the world over after his methods, was slain in heaps, and driven from the guns across the nullah, or khon. It is the lead rather than the steel that piles np the butcher's bill in ail modern wars. If the Der- vishes had pat more trust in their Remington rifles, what a different story there wonld have boon to tell of £udan warfare ! la their, famous charge at Omddrmtn, the 21st Lanoers inflicted relatively little hurt upon the enomy, until, Wheeling to the left, they dismounted and opened fire with their carbines. It was then that the Dervishes decamped out of the nnllah. Our casualties at Abu Kra came from tho good shooting of a few of the Mahdi's black Kordofan hunters. General Stewart, 8t. L*g*r, Cameron, and others being killed by the Dervish fi-e, which came pelting at times like hail amongst ns. I was hit in the neck, and it was only by poshing forward and oocnpying a knoll, from which we oonld get at these deadly marksmen, that farther loss was avert- ed and the situation saved. We had with ns not a few excellent rifle-shots, including ser- geants in the Berkshire and other regiments who ware in the m mated infantry and camel corps contingents. I recollect many an oocaiion when *e used to creep oat, and, at ranges from 900 to 1,30.) yards, break np the oonstant attempts made by the Dervishes to drill their CORPORATtSPOF WE8TBBN

EGYPT, LTD. ( From "A1 Mokattam." ) Much interest hits bhen eXoited by the Ou- psny of the Oases. We have rooeiitly met an Egyptian engineer whb has resided nearly SO’ years in Australia and was. engaged‘m gold digging and other mining in that oOuntry. He has sinoe been seat by gold'mining companies to Um Rns and elsewhere to superintend Egyptian miners and teach them their srortr in those mines and has been sent by the Oases Company into the oases to prospect for mine1 rals there and remained there three months till he became fully acquainted with what was going on. His name it Shimi Bat ran. We askod him what ho saw there, and he replied,1 "So far as search for mines, which was an important part of my work^ is oonoorned, I saw many traces of old workings which may some day be again profitable. I was down 147 fret in one old shaft ahd fotnid affjofti-' ing it, 100 yards asJa^i traces of connect- ing workings, bat was' obliged to give up for the time owing to the heat and sand after digging about 12 feet into it. "I found, however, many andentalmn work- ings white and rose colour and all colours in veins up to 18 incites thick. I marked the various beds by flags. I found a bod of (coal) lignite at about 16 to 20 foot deep, 3 to 6 inches thick, and 1 sunk below it to 85 feet hopiog for another vein, and I am of opinion that it Is absolutely necessary to make farther search before anyone can fay whether there is or is not plenty of coal there; also proper prospecting should bo done for gold. Four or five prospectors should be sent ont through all the oases, for there is certain to be plenty of valuablo minerals." We asked him about the land, and he said the soil was liko that of Nile Islands. He himself saw north of Um Dabadib a vast tract of land with tracos of houses and trees showing that it had boon cultivated, and had no doubt that if cnltivutod again it wonld be equal to any land in Egypt. "Also ^heikb Mnstapha Hanadi, Omdeh of Khorgoh, told me that cotton would grow there as well as in Egypt, and all the land, once water is brought to it, produces as well as the best -land in Egypt, and thought the oases land jost as the land in Egypt."

And we asked him whether there was water enough and he said that every proof exists and every experiment that had been tried shows that there is plenty of underground water. And the water rise* in artesian wells, and all the cultivation is done by them. The oompany sank an artesian well between Khargeh and the Deir, and another well in the Derr, and the water is flowing from both day and night and the laud around is being cultivated. "I dug S’x wells (ordinary) between Khargeh and the Deir and Mehriq and in moit of them found sweet water, some at 4 metres and sOme at 6 metres. Each well c let about 300 piastres to sink and the oases water is generally as sweet as the Nile, in fact I think there is plenty of sweet svater in the oases, and an enormous extent of land can be cultivated by boring iells."

We asked if there were many inhabitants in the oases. He answered, "They are not many and they do not pay proper attention to their cultivation, being lary and indolent. When I returned to the Nile Valley I met many people of Upper Egypt who said they wished to go and take op lands in the oases if the railway went there."

We asked about the railway, and be said : "All I know is that the company means to make one and is going about it, and it is poiitively certain that oine tho railway goes the oases will thrive and prosper exceedingly, but without the railway their riches must : remain undeveloped. However that is certain 1 to be done some time. (Communicated). 1

Any person wishing to bid for the above properties, either in whole or in port, most attend at the Delegation on the day above- mentioned to obtain a cahier des charges and make his offer. div.head: INDEMNITIES OF WAR SOME RECENT CASES.
div.p: In principle war indemnities may be regard- ed as "the coAts ol the action" ; in practice they are apt to become confounded with the object ot the quarrel. This was emphatically m tlie case of the ransom extorted from K- 'ine by the Gauls after the battle of the Allia ,,,330 B.' When Brennos tlsng bis sword and shield into the scales and cried, "Vn- victia," be atbnned a principle which is pro Kibly as ancient as human uature, and which has been tairly steadily maintained ever since. The amount of a war indemnity often depends iiite as much upon the auxiety of the van , ashed to escape further homiliation as upon ;Le victor's precise bill of expenses, tin the , ther haud, the sum is frequently reduced tlirough the sheer and manifest inability of the crushed combatant to pay the price of his own overthrow. Indeed, it is almost impossible to find an example in which some disturbing factor does tot interfere with the precise operation of the general law. Napoleon, for instance, cost Great Britain alonp the greater part of £831,000,000 before he was finally suppressed at Waterloo , but under the TREATY OF PARIS (1815). France paid only ........ £28,000,000 to England, Pmssia, and Rnssia together. In the impoverished condition of Lonis XVIII.'s dominions, however, it »as thonght advisable to spread even this comparatively modest reimbursement over a period of five years, and it was divider! into fifteen instalments of £1,.110,000 each, one of which fell due every four months. Coming to more recent times, we find in 1^71 what is always regarded as the supreme exaiup’e of a war indemnity. Under the TREATY op FRANKFORT, 1871, France paid a ransom of . . £200,000,000. In demanding this colossal sum Bismarck had in bis mind two distinct intentions; They were to replenish Germany's emptied war chest and by crippling her antagonist financially to pre- vent her from reviving to a condition in which she could have renewed boAilities before time bad soothed her wounded pride and assuaged the desire for "la revanche." That the latter purpose might more completely be fulfilled, payment in cash, and over a very short period, was imposed. The first instalment was £20,000,000, and it was provided by the stipu- lations of the treaty that it should be banded over one month after the French Government had obtained possession of Paris from the Commune. A further £40,000,000 was to be liquidated before the end ot the year, £20,00o,imore on May 1, 1872, and the balanoo of £1801000,000 on May 2, 1874. Moreover," interest at the rate of 5 per oent had to be paid until tho money had actaally changed hands. The manner in which France discharged this enormons debt is one of the most remarkable displays of the latent wealth of a nation to be found in history. To the astonishment of the whole world, the entire £2u0,O00,OO0 was placed at the disposal of the conqueror six months before the expiry of the prescribed term.

Another large indemnity of recent times was that exacted by Rnssia from Tnrkey in 1878, aftet the Tsar’s armies had fought their way to the gates of Constantinople. The terms agreed to at San Stefano underwent consider- able modification at the subsequent Interna- tional Congress, bat under the TREATY OP BERLIN, Turkey undertook to pay..£32,000,000. It was stipulated, however, that the Otto- man Government, never a very prompt settler of accounts, should be allowed a long period of years in which to find the money. Some of it is still owing. Japan has a precedent of her own in this matter, an indemnity having form- ed an important feature in the fruits of her triumph over China in 1895. The amount demanded was considerably increased after the intervention of Russia, Germany, and France had deprived the victorious islanders of the Liao-tung peninsula and the fortress of Port Arthur. Under the eventual TREATY OP 8HIMONOSBKI, China paid 200,000,000 taels. This woald beequivalent toabout£26,000,000 in English currency. Turkey was very anxious to obtain a substantial indemnity from Greeoe in 1897, but a financial commission appointed by the Powers reported that the defeated bel- ligerent oould not arfford to satisfy the Otto man demand, and £4,000,000 was in'theend fixed upon as the outside limit of the pecuniary compensation in this case. At the conclusion of hostilities between the United States and Spain was seen the nnosual spectacle of the victor paying an indemnity, as a kind of sb change in return for territorial concessions that seemed rather more than the circumstances of he case required.

THE REPORT OF THE COMPANY. BRITAIN’S WORK IN EGYPT. The report of the Suez Canal Company- gives some interesting details with regard to the various shipping companies whose vessels used this great waterway laet year. As wo pointed out when dealing with the summary of tho report the progress made by British ship- ping at Urge is very marked, and it now appears that tho number of passages made by British vessels was 2,679, with a total net tonnage of 8.834,000, Germany, tho near- est competitor, recording 542 passages, with a net tonnage of 1,969,000. The distribution of this tonnage amongst the various lipes, as given in the report, is as follows Company. Tonnage.

As printed, this list is calcnUted in some respects to produce a slightly wrong impres- sion of the status of the various lines. Por example, the Hall Line and the City Line are both owned by the Ellerman Lines, Limited, and if these two totals were added together, as they Bhonld properly be, that oompany would rank third on the list, as against the total tonnage of any other—British or foreign—and teoond if compared with British lines only. This mast be regarded as a highly satisfactory rooord for a combination which has been in existence only about four years. Of the list as a whole, it may be said that it is most credit- able to British shipowners, and shows very clearly their greatly preponderating share in the business of the Canal.

A FRENCH COLONI AL OFFICIAL* OPINION. In tho course of an interview with the re- presentative of the "African World" M.Salesses Administratenr-en-chef in the Prench Colonial Service aud Director of the Nigor-Konakiy Railway, made the following observations on his visit to the Upper Nile, Uganda, and British E. Africa.

"Haviog been kindly supplied with letters commendatory by M. Dolcassc, I visited Egypt, and at Cairo wi s received by Lord Cromer and Lord E-lwaid Cecil, Agent General for the Sudan at Cairo, to both of whom I am most grateful—as, indeed, to the British officials everywhere--for many kindnesses.After having inspected the Egyptian railways with the aid of M. Barois, the French administrator of Egyptian railways, I was able to see the Assouan dam, thanks to Sir William Gantin. It is magnifioent; a groat work. At Wady- Halfa I inspected the workshops of the Sudan Government Railways, through the kindness of Captain Midwinter, the assistant manager of the line. A railway U being Uid from Atbara to Sheikh Bxrgut, now called Bandar Sndan, and fifty mile* of the work had already been completed. At Khartoum, in the Sirdar's absence, 1 »oi received by Colonel Henry. Khartoum looks well. It is astonishing how much has been done in so short a time. It U said that the country between KassaU and Khartoum and the banks of the Blue Nile is exceedingly rich and good ooontry. I left Khartoum by steamer for Gondokoro. There are four steamers at work clearing the sudd, a work which is indispensable for the navigation of the White Nile. After visiting Lado and Gondokoro I was provided by Mr. Spire, Col- lector of Gondokoro, with forty carriers, and traveled tho Uganda Protectorate on foot, visiting the posts ot Nimnle, Wadelai, and Bulraba (on Lake Albert Nyanza), Hoima and Kampala, and finally Entebbe, on the shores of the Victoria Nyanza, the main town of Uganda. 1 saw on this part of my journey very many buffalo, elephants, harts boost, oribes, waterbneks, and some baheoiceps of Schwein- furth. At Entebbe 1 was the guest of Mr. Wilson, the Acting Commissioner of the Uganda Protectorate.

UGANDA PROSPECTS. "I found the ooontry looking very well and prosperous. The people are chiefly oatives, but there arc also Indian traders and a few Euro- peans. The natives are peaceable, a fine race physically, and not very difficult to govern. I think it is a wise policy to have built the Uganda railway, and that several other lines should be bnilt rather than money be spent on outting new roads, inasmuch as horses and mules die, and the country is too wet for oamels. Prom Butraba to Entebbe the climate is perfect, and I think the country is van suitable for Europeans. It is the land of the elephant. Thera is much trade in ivory, and they have good hopes for rubber. I believe it would pay the country to build two railways, the first trom Gondokoro to Nimule, 100 miles, and the other from Butraba to Entebbe, 200 miles. There is a sufficiency of good native labour, and the oost would not be great, if the management were intelligent. 1 left Entebbe and crossed the Viotoria lake by the steamer • Winifred," oalling at Jinja, where I saw the Ripon Palls, that is, the beginning of the Nile, At Kisomu (Port Florence) I took the Uganda railway, and stopped at Nairobi, where I had the pleasure of meeting the general manager of the line, Mr. Currie, to the excellence of whose direction I wish to testify. The line is well bnilt I believe, ss 1 have said, that fur* ther railway construction in Uganda is necess sary, and that when Uganda is folly develop* ed, both it and the East African Protectorate will be successful colonies. The climate of the East African Protectorate is admirably suited to Europeans. It is astonishing to see ante- lopes, giraffes, zebras, gazelles, ostriches, and more occasionally lions and rhinoceroses along the line. Leaving Nairobi I reached Mombasa, where I crossed Lord Milner, who had oome from Durban, and was inspecting the Uganda railway.

THE COST OF AN ARTIFICIAL SEA. EGYPT EXPLORATION PUND. In seeking for a reservoir for the supply of Egypt during the dry season, it is not to be wondered at .that the reconstruction of the ancient Lake of Moeris should have been care- 1 fully considered. As, however, in the bed of tho lake is a fertile province, with a cultiv- able area of 400,000 acres and a value of 80,000,000/., its construction on its original site is oat of the question ; but there exists a tmailer depression in the Libyan hills immediately to the sooth, to which no suoh objections apply. This depression is' known ss the Wady Rayan ; and Mr. Cope Whitehouse, the disooveror of Lake Moeris, ' has for yean insisted that in taming theWady . Rayan into an artificial lake or reservoir lay the true solution of the problem of Egypt's ! water supply. In area at a level of 29 metres j above that of the sea would be about 700 square kilometres, or 270 square miles When full, its greatest depth would be 70 metres, though only the upper 4 or 5 metres would bo used annually, giving a possible supply cf some 3 milliards of oubio metres out of a total contents of 20 milliards. Mr. Cope Whitehouse maintains that the entire work necessary can ho done at a oost of 600,000/ He has offered many times to undertake the contract for the work on the basis of this estimate, or to carry it oat as a private speculation, subject to equit- able terms of purchase by the Egyptian Go- vernment when oompleted. It is unpleasant to know that these offers have been rejected again and again ; not because of any engineer- ing reasons, but that the Government preferred to leave a great part of Egypt trows tored until they possessed the inclination and money to do the work themselves. However, whether it is to cost 600,000/. or 2,600,000/., the estimate of Sir W. Willoocks, the outlay will bring an enonnons and immediate return, and the names of those who have assisted in bringing it to completion will deserve remembrance among the greatest benefactors of Egypt. ("Engineering.")

A PIGMY TRIP. The pigmies who have temporarily exchang- ed Darkest Africa for Dampest England had their first motor ride yesterday, says Monday week's "Pall Mall Gazette," bat there seems to be no means of obtaining a satisfactory state- ment of their impressions. Their only remark on the trip was, "Umgari," which is supposed, we are told, to be Pigmyeae for "good." But it seems just as likely to be the equivalent of the "No pusbee, no pollee, go like bailee," which is the first rooord ed sooonnt by a Chinese descriptive reporter ot an electric tramway. The majority of the party spent the journey in slumber, bat the yoangest made np for this stolidity by tasting the lubricating oil and emptying the remainder over the vehicle, after which be overhauled the machinery to inch purpose that the homeward trip was completed m a cab. Understanding that they were to traverse the del ole te mileage of the Brighton road, the distinguished tourists were allowed to wear their full equipment of spears and arrows, but, as there were no signs of the Marquis of Queensberry being on the warpath, the expedition was fortunate enough to return scatheless.

The following letter appears "iu^the "Times":— Sir,— Onr attention has been called^to a communifui paragraph with regard to the establishment of a British School of Arohmo- logy in Egypt, which has appeared in several of the morning papers. While we refrain from discussing the desirability or the prospects-of such a school, we must express our surprise that in this announcement the existence of the Bgypf Exploration Fund through the aid of which Professor Flinders Petrie has in the main been enabled to carry on hie important work in Egypt, is entirely ignored. The tyt is thst, although the arrangement between Professor Petrie and the fond is for the present suspended by mutunl consent, he has during the past nine yean not only received from-the fond a regular salary and has been allowed travelling and personal expenses while in Egypt, bat he has also had placed at his disposal an aggregate sum of upwards of £7,000 for the purposes ot exploration. We venture, through your kind assistance, to remind the subscriber* to the Egypt Exploration Fund of this fact, and to express a hope not only that existing subscriptions may not be diverted elsewhere, bat that the fond which liu already done so much in the past to make known in this ooontry the history oi ancient Egypt may reoeive a still wider support

Although for the moment it is doubtful whether, from financial considerations, large exoavations can at present be undertaken by the fund, the committee hope that work may be resumed at the unique temple of Mentu- hotep at Deir-el-Bahari and brought to a dose in the ensuing season.
Yours faithfully, JOHN BVAN8, President, HERBERT A. GRUBBER, Treasurer, Egypt Exploration Fund, 37, Great Rossell- street, W.C., Jane 16. COTTON GROWING IN THE WEST INDIES.

Evidence of the confidence that is felt in the fntnre of ootton growing in the West Indies is afforded by the announcement in the "Agricultural News," the official organ of the Agricultural Department of the West Indies, that it is proposed, in view of the progress made in oonoeotion with the Sea Island ootton industry in the West Indies, to ereot a small plant at Barbados for sx tree ting and refining the oil to be obtained from the seed. The project is receiving the support of the British Cotton Growing Association. The establish- ment is expected to be ready to begin opera- tions early next year, and it will be the first Ootton oil factory to be orected in the British West Indies. As to its immediate outlook, it is estimated that the total crop of Sea Island ootton for the current season will be about 8,000 bale*, which will probably yield some 1,660 tons oi seed. The yield of crude oil is about 45 gallons per ton of reed, so that if the whole of the seed were available for the factory the ontpat of erode oil woald be eboat 74,900 gallons.
